perturbation.original_text: 10.1 Initial Term. This Agreement will become effective as of the Effective Date and, unless sooner terminated pursuant to Sections 3.1  [Advertising and Promotion] or 10.2  [Termination for Breach], shall remain effective for two (2) years from and after the Effective Date (the "Initial Term"). This agreement shall automatically renew for additional successive terms of twelve (12) months each at the end of the Initial Term ("Renewal Terms"), unless either party notifies the other in writing at least sixty (60) days prior to the end of the Initial Term. As used in this agreement, "Term" shall mean the Initial Term and the Renewal Terms, if any.
perturbation.changed_text: 10.1 Initial Term. This Agreement will become effective as of the Effective Date and, unless sooner terminated pursuant to Sections 3.1  [Advertising and Promotion] or 10.2  [Termination for Breach], shall remain effective for two (2) years from and after the Effective Date (the "Initial Term"). This agreement will renew only upon the written agreement of both parties to extend the term. As used in this agreement, "Term" shall mean the Initial Term and any mutually agreed upon Renewal Terms, if any.
perturbation.explanation: Section 10.1 originally stated the agreement would automatically renew for 12-month terms unless one party gave 60-day written notice. The revision removes the automatic renewal, mandating explicit written agreement from both parties for any extension of the Term. This creates a direct contradiction on renewal conditions, making it unclear if the contract renews automatically or requires a mutual written agreement.

perturbation.original_text: 5.1 During the Term, (a) Women.com will not buy, sell, display, distribute advertising from (including, but not limited to, banner ads, buttons, badges, text links, hyperlinks or editorial mentions) or otherwise promote a Competitive Company on any page of the Diet Center; (b) eDiets will be the exclusive third party provider of content and interactive tools for diets and diet counseling to Women.com within the Diet Center; (c) Women.com will not enter into a relationship with a Competitive Company that involves any of the following; (i) custom developed mini or micro web sites; (ii) content integration; (iii) discounts offered only to Women.com members on the Member Central page of the Women.com Sites; (iv) editorial endorsement (such as
perturbation.changed_text: 5.1 During the Term, (a) Women.com may, at its sole discretion, buy, sell, display, distribute advertising from (including, but not limited to, banner ads, buttons, badges, text links, hyperlinks or editorial mentions) or otherwise promote a Competitive Company on any page of the Diet Center; (b) eDiets will be the preferred, but not exclusive, third party provider of content and interactive tools for diets and diet counseling to Women.com within the Diet Center; (c) Women.com will freely enter into a relationship with a Competitive Company that involves any of the following; (i) custom developed mini or micro web sites; (ii) content integration; (iii) discounts offered only to Women.com members on the Member Central page of the Women.com Sites; (iv) editorial endorsement (such as
perturbation.explanation: Section 5.1 originally stated the agreement will not advertise for competitors. The revision introduces a contradiction that Women.com may promote competitors. This creates a direct contradiction on exclusivity, making it unclear if the contract has exclusivity or is non-exclusive

perturbation.original_text: 11.8 The terms and conditions of this Agreement will be deemed to be the Confidential Information of each party and will not be disclosed without the written consent of the other party.
perturbation.changed_text: 11.5 Notwithstanding the foregoing, each party may disclose Confidential Information (a) to the extent required by a court of competent jurisdiction or other governmental authority or otherwise as required by law, provided that the Receiving Party uses reasonable efforts to provide the Disclosing Party with prior notice of such obligation in order to permit the Disclosing Party a reasonable opportunity to take legal action to prevent or limit the scope of such disclosure, or (b) on a "need-to-know" basis under an obligation of confidentiality to its legal counsel, accountants, banks and other financing sources and their advisors. 11.8 The terms and conditions of this Agreement can be disclosed by either party to potential investors or acquirers without obtaining the other partyâ€™s consent.
perturbation.explanation: Section 11.8 originally stated that the agreement cannot be disclosed without the consent of both parties. The revision introduces a loophole by stating that it can be disclsed to potential investors or acquirers without the other party's consent. This causes contradictions about confidentiality of the agreement terms.
